Award.AwardTitle: Reduced Basis for Gravitational Waves: Select, Solve, Represent, Predict
Award.AbstractNarration:
Binary systems composed of neutron stars, black holes, or a mixed pair are expected to be some of the most important sources for the upcoming generation of advanced earth-based gravitational wave detectors such as advanced LIGO. Numerous models exist for describing such systems, such as post-Newtonian, phenomenological, Effective One Body ones, and numerical simulations of the full Einstein equations (the field of numerical relativity). Regardless of the model to describe it, the problem suffers from a fairly large dimensionality. Roughly speaking, the number of configurations to study is too large for an exhaustive analysis. For this reason, large regions of the parameter space have been so far unexplored. Under this award, we will engage in a systematic study of the physical parameter space for gravitational waves from compact binary coalescences (CBC) using a Reduced Basis approach. Reduced Basis will be used for efficiently selecting within certain physical models for CBC the most relevant regions in parameter space to solve for and analyze, compactly representing the corresponding gravitational waves, and predicting new ones based on such selection.

Reduced Basis modeling is an active area of basic and applied research at the forefront of many fields, from climate studies and weather forecasting to gene classification and hyperspectral imaging. We envision that the techniques we will develop in our gravitational physics research will also find application in other fields. Additionally, as part of our outreach efforts, we will engage students from underrepresented groups. In particular, we will work with students from Howard University (one of the top HBCUs in the country) and give presentations at local Hispanic High Schools such as Cardozo and McCormick.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period 05/01/2014 to 04/30/2015 of this award, an innovative research program for fast simulations of the gravitational waves emitted from binary compact coalescences (CBC), such as binary neutron stars or black holes in real time, has been continued. This program has been able to show that supercomputer simulations solving the Einstein equations of General Relatiivty, which can take months using hundreds of processors can be replaced, with indistinguishable results, using a laptop or even a smart cell phone in less than a second. This simulation aspect of the problem is called the forward one, because of its predictive nature. 

The importance of such fast evaluations arises from the direct, expected detection over the next few years of gravitational waves from earth-based observatories such as Advanced LIGO, founded by the National Science Foundation. 

Similarly, in order to extract all available astrophysical information from any detected source there is a need to infer the sources in a reasonable time. This inference refers to, for example, whether the source corresponds to a pair of neutron stars or black holes, a mixed pair, as well as their masses and spins, and even model selection, such as testing Einstein's theory of gravity from alternative ones. This part of the problem, in turn, is called the inverse one. 

During this period of the project it has been shown that parameter estimation of the most likely sources to be detected (binary neutron stars) can be carried out by Advanced LIGO in over a few days of computation per signal, as opposed to months with previously available methods. The results of these developments have been implemented in the LIGO data analysis pipeline, are available to the whole collaboration, including its international partners, and is actively used.

This project has been developed within the Reduced Basis framework, and has shown that it has the promise of solving a decades long problem, namely, the forward and inverse problems of CBC in real time or nearly so, in a few more years of research and development.
